chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Progestogen-only implant
chapter.summary: Covers the use of the progestogen-only implant, including the available products; when to start it; the efficacy; the advantages, disadvantages, risks, possible adverse effects and key drug interactions; and follow up requirements for this method of contraception.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 13 years to 60 years (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Starting a progestogen-only implant
How should I assess a woman before providing her with a progestogen-only implant?
subChapters.htmlStringContent: • For information on assessing a woman who is considering starting a progestogen-only implant, see the section on Progestogen-only implant in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: When can the progestogen-only implant be inserted?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Specific advice for women who are amenorrhoeic, postpartum and breastfeeding, postpartum and not breastfeeding, post-termination of pregnancy or post-miscarriage is summarized in the section on Amenorrhoea, postpartum, termination of pregnancy, or miscarriage. 

  • The progestogen-only implant  (Nexplanon®) must only be inserted by healthcare professionals who have been appropriately trained and accredited.
  • If the woman is not currently using a regular method of contraception:
    • Ideally, insert the progestogen-only implant up to, and including day 5 of the menstrual cycle. 
      • No additional contraception is required.
    • If this is not possible, insert the progestogen-only implant at any other time in the menstrual cycle provided it is reasonably certain that the women is not pregnant and that there is no risk of conception.
      • Advise the woman to avoid intercourse or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 7 days.
  •  If the woman is starting the progestogen-only implant after oral emergency hormonal contraception:
    • For levonorgestrel, insert the implant immediately and advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 7 days.
    • For ulipristal acetate, insert the implant 5 days after taking ulipristal acetate and abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) during this time and for the first 7 days after the implant has been inserted.
    • Advise the woman to have a pregnancy test no sooner than 3 weeks after unprotected sexual intercourse (UPSI).
  • If the woman is replacing an old progestogen-only implant with a new one:
    • If replacement is at, or within the licensed duration of 3 years, remove the old implant and immediately insert a new implant.
      • No additional contraceptive cover is required.
    • If replacement is beyond the licensed duration of 3 years, remove the old implant and immediately insert a new implant provided it is reasonably certain that the woman is not pregnant and there has been no risk of conception.
      • Advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 7 days.
  • If the woman is changing from a combined hormonal contraceptive (CHC):
    • Insert the progestogen-only implant on day 1 of the hormone-free interval. 
      • No additional contraception is required.
    • If the implant is inserted on week 1 of normal CHC use: 
      • Advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 7 days.
      • If UPSI has occurred after day 3 of the hormone-free interval, advise restarting the CHC method for at least 7 days.
    • If the implant is inserted on weeks 2–3 of normal CHC use:
      • No additional contraceptive cover is required if the CHC method has been used consistently and correctly for the previous 7 days. 
  • If the woman is changing from the progestogen-only pill (POP) or levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG-IUS):
    • Insert the implant at any time in the menstrual cycle.
    • Advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 7 days, regardless of when in the menstrual cycle the implant is inserted. 
  • If the woman is changing from an injectable progestogen-only contraceptive:
    • Insert the progestogen-only implant when the repeat injection is due, or up to 14 weeks after the last injection was given.
      • No additional contraception is required.
    • If the implant is inserted more than 14 weeks after the last injection:
      • Advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 7 days. 
      • Emergency contraception will be required if UPSI occurs during this time.
  • If the woman is changing from a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms), or the copper intrauterine device (Cu-IUD):
    • Insert the progestogen-only implant on day 1–5 of the menstrual cycle.
      • No additional contraception is required.
    • If the progestogen-only implant is inserted at any other time in the menstrual cycle:
      • Advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 7 days.
      • The Cu-IUD should be retained for 7 days if UPSI occurred in the 7 days before the implant was inserted.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What progestogen-only implants are available?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Nexplanon® is currently the only progestogen-only implant licensed for use in the UK. 
    • It contains 68 mg of etonogestrel and comes in a preloaded applicator to reduce errors during insertion.
    • It is inserted under the skin (subdermally) in the inner part of the upper arm by healthcare professionals who have completed the appropriate training.
    • Designed to provide contraceptive cover for 3 years, it is radio-opaque and can be located by X-ray.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How do progestogen-only implants work?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The progestogen-only implant, Nexplanon®, prevents pregnancy by inhibiting ovulation. It also causes changes in cervical mucus that inhibit sperm.
  • Serum etonogestrel concentrations rise rapidly after insertion of the implant and ovulation is likely to be inhibited within 24 hours.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Amenorrhoea, postpartum, termination of pregnancy, or miscarriage
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If the woman is amenorrhoeic:
    • Insert the progestogen-only implant at any time if is reasonably certain the woman is not pregnant. 
      • Advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 7 days.
  • If the woman is postpartum (whether breastfeeding or not):
    • Insert the progestogen-only implant on or before day 21 postpartum. 
      • No additional contraception is required.
    • If the implant is inserted after day 21 postpartum, advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 7 days, unless menstruation has started and the implant is inserted on days 1-5.
  • If the woman has had a miscarriage or termination of pregnancy:
    • If gestation is less than 24 weeks, ideally insert the implant immediately after a miscarriage, surgical termination, or the first part of a medical termination.
      • If the progestogen-only implant is inserted within 5 days of miscarriage or termination, no additional contraception is required.
      • If the implant is inserted more than 5 days after miscarriage or abortion, advise the woman to abstain from sex or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) for 7 days.
    • If gestation is 24 weeks or more, treat as for a woman who is postpartum.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Types of implant
  • This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline, Progestogen-only implants [FSRH, 2014a], the Summary of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2016c] and information in the British National Formulary [BNF 71, 2016].
Mechanism of action
  • This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline, Progestogen-only implants [FSRH, 2014a], the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2016c] and information in the British National Formulary [BNF 71, 2016].
When to start
  • These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guidelines Progestogen-only implants [FSRH, 2014a], Contraception after pregnancy [FSRH, 2017b], and the UK Medical Eligibility Criteria for contraceptive use [FSRH, 2016], a statement from the FSRH clinical effectiveness unit [FSRH, 2015b], and the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2016c].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice should I give a woman who is considering using a progestogen-only implant?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Discuss:
    • The mechanism of action of the progestogen-only implant.
    • The advantages, disadvantages, and risks of the progestogen-only implant.
    • The efficacy of the progestogen-only implant.
    • What happens when the progestogen-only implant is removed.
      • Advise the woman that normal fertility should return as soon as the progestogen-only implant is removed.
  • Give advice on:
    • The possible adverse effects (such as menstrual irregularities) which may occur with the progestogen-only implant.
    • The possibility of drug interactions.
      • Advise the woman to check with a healthcare professional before starting any new drug treatment (including herbal remedies).
  • Provide written information on the progestogen-only implant.
    • The Family Planning Association provides a useful leaflet with information for users of the progestogen-only implant. 

[FSRH, 2014a]

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a woman who becomes pregnant whilst using the progestogen-only implant?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If a woman is found to be pregnant whilst using the progestogen-only implant:
    • Remove the implant.
    • Inform her that there is no evidence of harm to the baby or the mother if pregnancy occurs while using the progestogen-only implant.
    • Be alert to the possibility of an ectopic pregnancy. See the CKS topic on Ectopic pregnancy for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Information and advice
  • These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Progestogen-only implants [FSRH, 2014a].
Pregnancy
  • These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Progestogen-only implants [FSRH, 2014a] and the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2016c].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the advantages and disadvantages of the progestogen-only implant?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Advantages
  • The implant is very effective.
  • Users do not have to think about contraception for 3 years.
  • Sexual intercourse need not be interrupted to use the implant.
  • It can be used when breastfeeding.
  • Normal fertility returns as soon as the implant is removed.
  • It can be used in women for whom combined hormonal contraceptives are not recommended.
  • It may help alleviate dysmenorrhoea.
  • It may reduce the risk of endometrial cancer.
  • It is not associated with many serious adverse effects. 
    • There is little or no increased risk of venous thromboembolism, stoke, or myocardial infarction.  
    • It does not significantly adversely affect bone mineral density.
  • It is effective in women of all weights.
    • However, the manufacturers of Nexplanon® advises earlier replacement of the implant in 'heavier women', but do not provide guidance on the body mass index (BMI) above which the implant should be replaced earlier.

Disadvantages

  • About 50% of women will experience changes in menstrual bleeding, and bleeding patterns are likely to remain irregular.
  • Contraceptive efficacy is likely to be reduced in women using liver enzyme-inducing drugs.
  • An implant does not protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs).

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline, Progestogen-only implants [FSRH, 2014a] and the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2016c].

Progestogen-only implant and replacement in 'heavier' women
  • The manufacturer of Nexplanon® suggests that healthcare professionals can consider replacing the implant earlier for 'heavier' women, however it does not clarify a weight above which this should be done [ABPI, 2016c]. 
  • The FSRH suggests that 70 kg might be an arbitary indicator for being 'heavier' [FSRH, 2014a].
  • However, no increased risk of pregnancy has been demonstrated in women weighing up to 149 kg, but because of the inverse relationship between weight and serum etonogestrel levels, a reduction in the duration of contraceptive efficacy cannot be completely excluded [FSRH, 2014a].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the possible risks and adverse effects of the progestogen-only implant?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Menstrual irregularities — see the section on Unscheduled bleeding for more information.
  • Acne — acne may occur or worsen (or improve) in some women.
    • If acne occurs or worsens, consider prescribing suitable acne treatment. For more information, see the CKS topic on Acne vulgaris.
  • Effect on bone mineral density — advise that there is no evidence of a clinically significant effect on bone mineral density with use of the progestogen-only implant.
  • Complications of insertion and removal — Fitting and removing the implant requires a minor surgical procedure and may cause some pain, bruising, itching, or irritation.
    • The surgical procedure can rarely (less than 1 in 100 women) cause problems such as an abscess, scarring, and migration or expulsion of the implant.
    • There have been reports of Nexplanon® breaking or bending in situ which may lead to a slightly increased rate of etonogestrel release.
    • There have been reports of Nexplanon® being found in the vasculature (including the pulmonary artery) and chest wall.
  • Increased cancer risk — there is a possible increased risk of breast cancer. However, this risk is very small compared with the overall risk of developing breast cancer, and gradually disappears within 10 years after stopping the progestogen-only implant, after which the risk of developing breast cancer is the same as for women that have never used hormonal contraceptives. For more information about the risks, which are the same as for progestogen-only pills, see the section on Risks and adverse effects in the Scenario: Progestogen-only pill.
  • Venous thromboembolism (VTE)
    • Advise that there is little or no increase in risk of VTE associated with the use of progestogen-only implants.
  • There is no evidence that the progestogen-only implant causes:
    • Weight changes.
    • Headache.
    • Depression and mood changes.
    • Loss of libido.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guidelines Progestogen-only implants [FSRH, 2014a] and Problematic bleeding with hormonal contraception [FSRH, 2015c], the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2015], a Medicine and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA) Drug Safety Update Nexplanon (etonogestrel) contraceptive implants: reports of device in vasculature and lung [MHRA, 2016], and the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2016c].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage unscheduled bleeding in a woman using a progestogen-only implant?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Exclude and/or manage situations which could result in unscheduled bleeding, such as:
    • Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) — as a minimum, test for Chlamydia trachomatis. The risk of STIs is increased if the woman is under 25 years, has a new sexual partner, or has had more than one sexual partner in the last year. For more information see the CKS topic on Chlamydia - uncomplicated genital.
    • Pregnancy.
    • Gynaecological conditions such as cervical cancer — if this is suspected, refer the woman using a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks). For more information, see the CKS topic on Gynaecological cancers - recognition and referral.
    • Endometrial cancer — refer women aged 55 and older using a suspected cancer pathway referral (for an appointment within 2 weeks) if they have menstrual irregularities. Refer women younger than 55 years if they have risk factors for endometrial cancer and persistent, problematic bleeding after the first 3 months of use, or if they present with a change in bleeding pattern after at least 3 months of use.
      For more information, see the CKS topic on Gynaecological cancers - recognition and referral.
    • Drug interactions.
  • Consider performing a pelvic and speculum examination:
    • For persistent bleeding beyond the first 3 months of use — unscheduled bleeding is common in the first 3 months of starting a new hormonal contraceptive method.
    • For new symptoms or a change in bleeding after at least 3 months of use.
    • If the woman has not participated in the National Cervical Screening programme regularly. For more information, see the CKS topic on Cervical cancer and HPV.
    • If requested by the woman.
    • If there are other symptoms such as pelvic pain, dyspareunia, or post coital bleeding. 
  • If no other underlying cause of irregular bleeding is suspected, and speculum and pelvic examination is normal, the bleeding can be assumed to be caused by the progestogen-only implant. Providing the woman has no other symptoms:
    • Reassure the woman that unscheduled bleeding is common and that the bleeding pattern in the first 3 months is predictive of future bleeding patterns. 
    • As a general guide:
      • Around 2 in 10 women are amenorrhoeic.
      • Around 3 in 10 women have infrequent bleeding.
      • Fewer than 1 in 10 women have frequent bleeding.
      • Around 2 in 10 women have prolonged bleeding.
    • Continue with the implant if the woman is happy to continue.
    • However, if bleeding is problematic, consider treating with: 
      • A combined oral contraceptive (30–35 micrograms of ethinylestradiol with levonorgestrel or norethisterone) either cyclically or continuously for up to 3 months, provided it is not contraindicated (off-label use). For more information, see Scenario: Combined oral contraceptive pill in the CKS topic on Contraception - combined hormonal methods.
      • Mefenamic acid 500 mg two or three times a day (or tranexamic acid 1 g four times a day) for 5 days. For more information see the section on Prescribing information in the CKS topic on Menorrhagia.
    • If the woman does not want treatment, or treatment fails, remove the implant and decide with the woman on another method of contraception. For more information, see the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How effective is the progestogen-only implant at preventing pregnancy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• For a comparison of the efficacy of progestogen-only implants with other methods of contraception, see the section on Comparative effectiveness of contraceptive methods in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.
    • When used perfectly (consistently and correctly), 0.05% of women will conceive within the first year of use due to method failure.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Progestogen-only implants [FSRH, 2014a].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What advice should I give regarding potential drug interactions with the progestogen-only implant?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Liver enzyme-inducing drugs

  • Advise the woman that liver enzyme-inducing drugs may reduce the efficacy of progestogen–only implants. Examples of liver enzyme-inducing drugs are:
    • Antibiotics — rifampicin and rifabutin are very potent liver enzyme inducers.
    • Antiepileptic drugs such as carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, phenytoin, barbiturates, primidone, and topiramate.
      • Topiramate is associated with a risk of fetal malformations and can impair the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives. Before initiating topiramate in a woman of childbearing potential, pregnancy testing should be performed. The patient should be fully informed of the risks related to the use of topiramate during pregnancy. Ensure that women and girls of childbearing potential are advised that they should be using a highly effective method of contraception [ABPI, 2017]. 
    • Antiretrovirals such as ritonavir, ritonavir-boosted protease inhibitors, efavirenz, and nevirapine.
    • St John's wort — advise women using the progestogen-only implant not to take herbal products containing St John’s wort.
  • If a woman is on short-term treatment (2 months or less) with a liver enzyme-inducing drug:
    • Advise her to change to an alternative contraceptive method unaffected by liver enzyme-inducing drugs.
      • For example, remove the implant and have a one-off progestogen-only injection to cover the short-term treatment and for 28 days after.
    • If this is not acceptable or possible:
      • Continue the progestogen-only implant.
      • Advise the woman to avoid sexual intercourse or use a barrier method of contraception (such as condoms) while taking, and for 28 days after stopping, the liver enzyme-inducing drug.
    • Consider the need for emergency contraception if sexual intercourse has taken place while the efficacy of the progestogen-only implant may have been reduced, for example if the woman has already started treatment with a liver enzyme-inducing drug. See the CKS topic on Contraception - emergency for more information.
  • If a woman is on long-term treatment (more than 2 months) with a liver enzyme-inducing drug:
    • Advise her to change to an alternative contraceptive method unaffected by liver enzyme-inducing drugs.
    • Consider the need for emergency contraception if sexual intercourse has taken place while the efficacy of the progestogen-only implant is doubtful, for example if the woman has already started treatment with a liver enzyme-inducing drug. See the CKS topic on Contraception - emergency for more information.

Griseofulvin

  • Griseofulvin may reduce the contraceptive effect of progestogen-only implants — advise the woman to change to an alternative method of contraception unaffected by griseofulvin.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guidelines Progestogen-only implants [FSRH, 2014a] and Drug interactions with hormonal contraception [FSRH, 2012; FSRH, 2017a], and the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2016c].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What follow up should I arrange for a woman using the progestogen-only implant?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• No routine follow up is required once the progestogen-only implant has been inserted.
  • However, advise healthy women to return:
    • When it is time to have the implant removed — after 3 years for Nexplanon®, earlier for 'heavier' women.
      • The manufacturers do not provide guidance on the body mass index (BMI) above which the implant should be replaced earlier.
    • At any time if:
      • They cannot feel the implant.
      • The implant appears to have changed shape.
      • They notice any skin changes or pain at the site of the implant.
      • They become pregnant.
    • If they wish to discuss:
      • Changing to another method of contraception.
      • Adverse effects or other problems associated with the implant.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How long can the progestogen-only implant be left in place?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Replace Nexplanon® every 3 years.
  • The implant can be used until the age of 55 years, or until the menopause can be confirmed. 
    • If the woman is not amenorrhoeic, continue the progestogen-only implant over 55 years of age until she has been amenorrhoeic for 1 year. 
    • If the woman is amenorrhoeic, consider one of the following options:
      • For woman over the age of 50 years, check serum follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels on two occasions, with an interval of 6 weeks between tests. If both FSH levels are more than 30 IU/L, stop the progestogen-only implant after 1 year.
      • Continue the progestogen-only implant until the age of 55 years if required and requested.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guidelines Progestogen-only implants [FSRH, 2014a], Contraception for women aged over 40 years [FSRH, 2010b] and the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics [ABPI, 2016c].
